title: Sweet Treats and Substitutions for Holiday Baking

content: The winter holiday season is synonymous with sugar. Cookies for Santa, hot chocolate by the fire, gingerbread house decorating, and lots of desserts after festive meals. Rather than being a treat, these sweets can be a lot to control when you are also managing food allergies.

Dessert recipes typically call for many of the top nine food allergens, including wheat, dairy, egg, and nuts. I’m not a professional baker, but I’m an experienced food allergy mom who has learned how to work my way around a kitchen, including around those pesky allergens. I’m delighted to share some of my favorite allergy-friendly packaged saviors, my own go-to holiday confections, and a list of easy substitutions for your baking this season and beyond.

When my boys were diagnosed over a decade ago, the allergy-friendly packaged food scene was grim. There were simply very few options, leaving parents like me to figure out on my own how to make everything from scratch. This is not my strong suit, so I am so grateful that there has been an explosion over the years of “free-from” products that are available in grocery stores and online. Of course, everyone has different allergens and comfort levels with cross-contamination, so please read every label carefully to decide if it’s safe for your family.
bullets: YumEarth for top nine allergen-free candies, including candy canes, as well as a beautiful gingerbread house kit
Sweet Loren’s for the best cookies ever, which are also easy to roll out and decorate. They also have a new pie crust!
Supernatural Sprinkles are gluten-free, dye-free, and vegan with so many styles that are perfect for festive baking.
Guittard chocolate baking chips are top nine allergen-free and melt perfectly.
Free2b Foods for top nine allergen-free chocolates. We love their sunflower butter Sun Cups!

Vermont Nut Free Chocolates for a large variety of chocolate treats. Their facility is free from peanuts, tree nuts, eggs, sesame, shellfish, and fish. Note that many of their products do contain milk and soy, and they also make products with wheat/gluten in their facility.
No Whey Chocolates for an assortment of chocolate treats, including a super cute top nine allergen-free chocolate Advent calendar
Red Plate Foods for divine top nine allergen-free muffins, cookies, and even granola
Home Free Vanilla Cookies, which we use for pie crust

content: If you are looking for even more allergy-friendly brands, check out the Snack Safely website and Spokin app.
Interested in baking something sweet yourself? I’ve got you covered with some delicious treats I’ve been making on repeat during the holiday season.

I simplify this delicious tradition by using a variety of cookie dough flavors from Sweet Loren’s. I make them as they are right out of the package. Or I bring them to room temperature, roll them out with a rolling pin, and use cookie cutters to make holiday shapes. I cook them according to the directions on the package, and then we decorate them with our own dairy-free icing. I mix one container of Violife dairy-free cream cheese (contains coconut) with one bag of powdered sugar and mix until smooth. The more powdered sugar you add, the thicker the icing will be. We then top the cookies and icing with either Supernatural Sprinkles or crushed YumEarth candy canes. I love that my family gets to enjoy the tradition of making holiday cookies without having to create everything from scratch or worry about allergens.

sections.heading: Spice Cake
content: I made this cake this Thanksgiving, and it was a huge hit with my family. Use your favorite boxed vanilla cake mix. (We use Simple Mills, which is gluten-free but does contain almond flour; there are lots of options depending on which foods you are avoiding.) Make the cake according to the directions on the box, but then add ½ tablespoon of vanilla extract, one heaping tablespoon of pumpkin pie spice, and an additional teaspoon each of cloves and ginger if you want extra spice. I like to make this in a Bundt pan so it looks pretty, then sprinkle with powdered sugar through a mesh sieve to decorate it. This is particularly delicious with coffee for a breakfast treat.

If you’d like more ideas for allergy-friendly holiday baking recipes, check out the Allergic Living and Allergy Awesomeness websites. On my Hillary Tolle Carter blog, you can find my mom’s recipes for Pumpkin Ca-Pie (a cross between cake and pumpkin pie) and Lemonade Cake.

sections.heading: Substitutions for Allergy-Friendly Baking
content: I’ve figured out how to modify almost any recipe at this point. You just need a list of substitutions to enlist to make treats safe for your family. Here are some common swaps to get you baking in no time:
bullets: Wheat. Swap a certified gluten-free flour for wheat flour. We prefer Arrowhead Mills Organic All Purpose Gluten Free Flour. I also often pulverize Zego gluten-free oats in my blender and use oat flour in my baking.
Egg. Swap ¼ cup of applesauce or ¼ cup mashed banana for one egg. You can also substitute 1 tablespoon of ground flaxseed plus 3 tablespoons of water.

Milk. Swap a nondairy milk that is safe for your family for regular milk. I often use Oatly full-fat milk in my baking, but you can also use rice milk, almond milk, coconut milk, or soy milk, depending on your needs.

Butter. Don’t forget that butter is dairy! We use Earth Balance Organic Dairy Free Buttery Spread (contains soy). Earth Balance also has a soy-free version, and there are multiple dairy-free butter options, so check your local grocery store.
Chocolate. There are so many great dairy-free chocolate brands, including Enjoy Life, Free2b Foods, and No Whey Chocolates. Hershey’s original chocolate syrup is also dairy-free!

content: I hope this baking guide helps you this season as you whip up sweet treats for your family to enjoy and share. We are lucky to have so many options for free-from packaged foods and great resources for allergy-friendly recipes. When all else fails, you can make your own goodies from scratch by simply swapping out your allergens for safe options that work for you. Enjoy the holiday season … and the holiday baking!
